Name: Small Papyrus Box of Tutankhamun
Description: This unique small box is made of papyrus fiber. It is from the collection of Tutankhamun. The scenes on it suggest it might have been made to keep the ceremonial objects of the king's coronation, or ceremony of being crowned. On the lid, the king is kneeling in the middle on a basket. He is wearing the double crown of Upper and Lower Egypt. He is kneeling between Amun-Re, king of the gods, and his wife, the goddess Mut, who helps in the ceremony. The side shows a scene of the coronation by Ptah, god of creation and patron deity of artists and craftsmen, and his wife the lioness Sekhmet, goddess of war. The main coronation ceremony traditionally took place in the temple of Ptah at Memphis.
